projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Liquor Alchahe≈øt, OR A DISCOURSE Of that Immortal Di≈ø≈øolvent OF Paracel≈øus & Helmont.

It being one of tho≈øe two Wonders of ART and NATURE, which radically di≈ø≈øolves all Animals, Vegitables and Minerals into their principles, without being in the lea≈øt alter'd, either in weight or activity, after a Thou≈øand Di≈ø≈øolutions, &c.

q.p:
Quicun
que ergo Medicinae operam datis ≈øummo ≈øtudio id adniti debetis ut Alchae≈øt praeparare di≈øcatis propter aver≈øionem multorum morborum qui ab Haepate oriuntur &c.

bibl.hi: Paracel≈ø. Archidox lib. de viribus membrorum cap. 6. de viribus Hae ‚Ä¢ atis.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by T. R. & N. T. for W. Cademan at the Popes-Head in the Lower Walk of the New-Exchange, 1675.

div.head: To the truly Honourable ROBERT BOYLE, E≈øq
div.p:
THAT I have made choice of your Honour to Patronize this Po≈øthume Tract, will appear no wonder to ≈øuch that have
been acquainted with your knowledge in this more occult Philo≈øophy of the Adepti≈øts, as well as with your Candour to encourage ≈øuch who have been but pretenders to Pyrotechny. I know
well, you affect not Flattery; and for me to ≈øpeak much, would but le≈ø≈øen, the World having been (by ≈øo many) acquainted with your worth. All the excu≈øe I make your Honour is, That
the pre≈øent Treati≈øe is yours by Right, the Author having in his Pyrotechny A≈ø≈øerted, begun this Di≈øcour≈øe, ≈øo that I only ≈øurrender what's your own. If the Noblene≈øs of the Subject be
not ≈øufficient to plead my excu≈øe for this Dedication, I hope your wonted Charity to forgive others, will not be ≈øtraitned to me, ≈øince I had no other Ambition in the Publication thereof, then the
promoting the publick good, by in≈øpiriting others to do the like, and giving this further te≈øtimony of my ≈øelf, that I am

closer.signed: Your Honours Obliged Humble Servant J. ASTELL.

postscript.p: From the Golden Globe again≈øt Strand-Bridge.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
AFter a long debate with my ≈øelf, I found I was obliged to put forth this little Tractate, not only to ≈øhow my ju≈øtne≈øs to the Dead, but my de≈øires of gratifying the living; for in an Age
wherein this kind of Philo≈øophy receives ≈øuch great incouragement (having acquired many eminent Practitioners as well as Patrons) and by the happy di≈øcovery of diligent ≈øearchers, hath made ≈øo large an improvement: I thought I could do no le≈øs then communicate this E≈ø≈øay concerning the Immortal Liquor Alchahest, that being the great
Key which unlocks Natures choice≈øt Secrets; and which at pre≈øent is ≈øo diligently ≈øought after. The Author of it was a per≈øon ≈øo indu≈øtriou≈øly laborious in the ≈øearching after natures choice≈øt my≈øteries, that he ≈øpared not for pains nor costs in the hunting after the true knowledge of the most ab≈øtruce Philo≈øophy. That his acquirements
were great, is not unknown to the World, e≈øpecially to tho≈øe who had any intimate familiarity with him, his Writings te≈øtifie his ability in the Philo≈øophy, or learning of the Schools, as well as in that of Nature, his di≈øcoveries having truly intituled him Philo≈øophus per Ignem. It was his misfortune to ju≈øtifie Truth in an Age when Chymi≈øtry had few
Friends that dur≈øt appear to ju≈øtifie her, yet ≈øo great an effect had his Writings, back'd with Truth, that the Eyes of many were opened, and occa≈øioned ≈øeveral to become Pro≈øelytes to Pyrotechny. It would not, I believe, le≈ø≈øen the e≈øteem of ≈øome eminent Practitioners, ≈øhould they acknowledge with me, that they had from him tho≈øe true fundamentals of Art
that hath rendred them thus famous. So that this pre≈øent Age reaps the benefit of his more early Studies. Had he not met with many Cro≈ø≈øes and Troubles, doubtle≈øs his di≈øcoveries had been greater; and had not he been cut off by that raging Pe≈øtilence, 1666. When he was ju≈øt ri≈øing out of tho≈øe Clouds which Eclip≈øed his worth, it would quickly
have appeared to the World, notwith≈øtanding the malice of his Enemies, That he was a true follower of Nature. Pyrotechny hath not had a bolder Champion; and I verily believe, many of his Enemies will now confe≈øs, they are convinced of the inefficacy of Vulgar Medicaments; and that there is an ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity for a new method of
Phy≈øick, as to the Pharmalentick part: for dayly ≈øuch incroachments are made upon this noble faculty, that if not ≈øpeedily prevented, it will be of little or no e≈øteem. The Common method of Phy≈øick being pa≈ø≈øed into the hands of all kind of unletter'd People; and the chief remedy that is left, would be a diligent inquiry after noble Medicines,
≈øuch that are agreeable to Nature, which the Author of this Tract candidly did not only hint at, but di≈øcover as plainly as it was fit, without incurring the ≈øame inconveniencies as did attend the making publick the Common method of Phy≈øicks which faults are not only to be taken notice of on the Gallenical part, but likewi≈øe tho≈øe abu≈øes are to
be con≈øider'd which have ≈øprung from Chymistry. It being common in this latter Age, for many to cry up them≈øelves for great Chymi≈øts, who (ignorantly decrying all others) have hardly known well the Names, (much le≈øs the u≈øes of Chymical Ve≈ø≈øels) the≈øe Men have had the impudence to impo≈øe on the World Trifles, for ∆≤niver≈øal Remedies; many
of which undi≈øcreetly admini≈øtred, have truly cured all Di≈øea≈øes; by giving the unwary Patients their Pa≈øports into another World. But I ≈øhall pa≈øs them over, as being unworthy my time to particularize their Cheats, which I have not patience to think of, nor can any true Son of Art con≈øider without re≈øentment, the abu≈øes that are daily
committed by this Farrago of Impo≈øtors, that have been, and will ever be, a di≈øhonour to the hone≈øt Profe≈ø≈øors of Pyrotechny. The only expedient in this Ca≈øe, wherein the good of Mankind is concerned, the Lives of Per≈øons being more to be valued, then all other worldly con≈øideraoions, is this; for ≈øome well experienced Artists, to put to
≈øale to the World, ≈øuch true Remedies, with their u≈øes, as may be benificial for the eradicating of Di≈øea≈øes, Medicines that have been known to be ≈øucce≈øsful by reiterated experiments, not tho≈øe duely made, not conjectural. By this means the honour of that mo≈øt noble faculty of Phy≈øick will be recover'd and advanced, and the truth of
Chymical Remedies will be manifested, notwith≈øtanding the reproaches of malicious gain-≈øayers. This the noble Helmont did; and by this way will it ≈øoon appear, whether or no tho≈øe refined Chymical Medicaments, are not more ≈øafe, more ea≈øie, and more effectual for eradicating of Di≈øea≈øes, then the Common Gallenical apparatus of Medicine. But ≈øuch
Arti≈øts, whoever they be that will thus expo≈øe any thing for the good of Mankind, I am ≈øure will be more ingenious then tho≈øe undi≈øcreet pretenders to Chymi≈øtry, as to make the World believe, That an univer≈øality of healing Di≈øea≈øes, can any way be expected from any one particular Medicine; it being impo≈ø≈øible, were they Ma≈øters of the
Grand Elixar, with that to cure all Di≈øea≈øes. I come now to ≈øpeak ≈øomething concerning the Author of this Tract, who was Dr. George Starkey, (my very good Friend) a Man who≈øe Writings ≈øpoke him more to the World then his Per≈øon or Di≈øcour≈øe;Natures Explication, & Helmonts Vindication. Pyrotechny A≈ø≈øerted. who≈øe moral failings I dare no more justifie, but he was a Man,
and as ≈øuch, the be≈øt of us are ≈øubject to erre, which con≈øideration ≈øhould ingage our Charity to forget. When imployed in Pyrotechnies School, Nature had not a more diligent Scholler; and who, to my own knowledge (not in vain) wrought for many years upon this Subject he di≈øcour≈øes of.

I mu≈øt confe≈øs, I never could get a ≈øight of the
Alchahe≈øt perfected by him, whether occa≈øioned by the importunities of Patients for Remedies, who≈øe condition would not admit the tarrying for Medicines of ≈øo high a preparation, or his want of conveniencies, being hurried from place to place, I know not, yet have I ≈øeen and known him, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor of ≈øeveral Magi≈øteries, and not many Months before his
death, I knew him Ma≈øter of a mercurial Medicine, who≈øe effects were ≈øuch, That it merited the name of an Arcanum. Had he lived, I know not what greater proofs he might have given of the certainty of ≈øuch an univer≈øal Solvent. His Arguments deduced from tho≈øe hints the mo≈øt noble Helmont gives are con≈øiderable, if duely weighed; and the true ≈øearchers
after Truth may receive no ≈ømall Light from him; for my own part, I have no rea≈øon to repent my Labours, and time ≈øpent in this Study, Nature being very Grateful to her diligent followers. From this Fountain have I gain'd a Salt, which di≈ø≈øolved in Rain Water,
arsenic being amalgam'd with another Metal, this being cau≈øed to boil in a Sand Furnace for the
≈øpace of two hours the Amalgame was di≈ø≈øolved into a Liquor, with as much ea≈øe as Sugar di≈ø≈øolves in Water. This I did in the pre≈øence of two Friends, no mean Arti≈øts. Therefore not to be impo≈øed upon, with which Medicine, my Men≈øtruum being ≈øeparated from it, and further operated on, I cured deploracle Poxes, &c. I ≈øhall forbear to di≈øcour≈øe any further, what
other medioaments I have made by the help of good Di≈ø≈øolvents, re≈øolving, if God ≈øpare me life, to put forth Pyrotechny Triumphant, which the Author, had he lived, intended to do, which will be an Explanation of his Pyrotechny A≈ø≈øerted, and Explication of the Hi≈øtory of Nature, comprehended in tho≈øe Subjects.

div.head: Liquor Alchahest, &c.
div.p:
I am come now to the di≈øcovery of the great Circulate, or immortal di≈øolvent of Paracel≈øus, and Helmont, not laying here the foundation of its U≈øe and Excellency, which I pre≈øume is ≈øufficiently believ'd in the World already, who had rather now hear tidings how it may be attain'd, then be tantaliz'd with a large Encomium
of its worth and value. I el≈øewhere taught its Nature, Nativity and Efficacy, although briefly I ≈øhall here come to a more large handling of it, yet with caution as well as candor. It is (as I ≈øaid) a Spiritual Salt, or Saline Spirit, which by rea≈øon of its tran≈øcendent purity, cannot be corruptively di≈ø≈øipated, and not finding any body ≈øo noble (at lea≈øt more noble) then it ≈øelf; di≈ødains to be wedded unto any, nor is it capable of a diver≈øe ferment from it ≈øelf, and ≈øo not liable to tran≈ømutation: the knowledge and preparation of it, is the work
of mo≈øt ab≈øtruce Philo≈øophy, the hope and crown of the adepti. O immortal Ens or Liquour! which penetrates all bodies, and perfectly reduces them to their fir≈øt Ens or matter, without any lo≈øs of virtue, or pondus, but remains in number, weight, and mea≈øure, the ≈øame after a 1000 times acting upon bodily concretes; only one conquers and ≈øubjugates it, and is in it ≈øelf de≈øtroyed in its de≈øtruction. It is vile and yet precious, it co≈øts nothing, every man hath it, the poor as well as the rich; Adam carryed it with him out of Paradice, it is mo≈øt
≈øecret in Microco≈øme, mo≈øt potent in the Macroco≈øme; it de≈øtroys and conquers all bodies, and ≈øubjugates the mo≈øt rebellious nature. 'Tis the product of Urine, then which nothing more common to come by, nothing more difficult to work on, well therefore ≈øaid Helmont, that its preparation was mo≈øt tedious: And mo≈øt truly wrote he of ≈øuch as contemn ≈øo vile and ≈øordid a thing, and di≈ødain to learn by the fire what its contents are, That true Wi≈ødom doth and will de≈øpi≈øe them. For the plainer unfolding the my≈øtery of its nativity and preparation, I
≈øhall recite my own broileries, how I hunted after it, and how after many years ≈øearch, and and infinite errors, I at length attained it, if there be any thing de≈øerving imitation in my example, follow it, and perhaps (God ble≈ø≈øing your ≈øtudies, labours & watchings) you may at la≈øt attain your de≈øires, as I, through the unde≈øerved mercy of God, at la≈øt attained mine. I had not been long conver≈øant in the writings of that noble Phylo≈øopher; but I ≈øoon (from ≈øome of his expre≈ø≈øions) gathered a ≈øtrong pre≈øumption, that Urine was the ≈øubject. E≈øpecially from
that place in his Trac. de Lith. where he thus ≈øpeaks, E≈øt in Natura univer≈øi, &c. There is in the whole nature of the Univer≈øe, but only one fire, (which is our con≈øuming Vulcan) and ≈øo likewi≈øe there is but one only Liquor which is of power to di≈ø≈øolve all ≈øolid bodies into their fir≈øt matter, without being its ≈øelf in the lea≈øt changed or weakned in its virtue; which tho≈øe that are adept know and can te≈øtifie. But in the activity of other Spirits, the di≈ø≈øolvable bodies can never radically mix them≈øelves with the di≈ø≈øolving Liquor; and therefore, though
they are corroded, yet is not this to be e≈øteemed an intire di≈ø≈øolution, for every acid Spirit (being corro≈øive) by corroding another body, is coagulated, and in a manner fixt, and becomes tran≈ømuted into the form of a conden≈øed Salt, not that the body, which (without alteration) endured what the pontick Spirit could work upon it, acts any thing towards its coagulation, but it ≈øelf by its proper corro≈øive activity, is Coagulated of its own accord. Thus far Helmont in that place, who el≈øewhere ≈øpeaking of his examination of all Salts, by way of Analyzing them, found
by all trials po≈ø≈øible, that their Spirits were ≈øtill acid, except only Alcalizate Salts, and tho≈øe of the E≈ø≈øential Sulphurs of vegetals. The Spirit of Mans Urine, notwith≈øtanding, was neither Acid nor Alcalizate, but meerly Saline, al≈øo the Spirit of the Urine of Bea≈øts. Hence I concluded, that in one of the≈øe two the Immortal Liquor mu≈øt find its primitive original, having on good rea≈øon, excluded all acid Spirits; (and by con≈øequence the Spirits of all other Salts in the World) Nor was the controver≈øie long deciding between Alcalizate
and Urinous Salts, con≈øidering the words of Helmont: when (≈øaith he) I di≈øtingui≈øhed between the ‚òøies, and the Salts and üúçs of Concretes, by an analytical re≈øolution of them, I wondred at the ≈øluggi≈øh, inactive nature of the ‚òøial compared to the dignity and excellent activity of the other two principles (to wit Sulphurous and Saline) Moreover I found, ≈øaith he, tho≈øe Salts more dull and languid, which partaked of the nature of üúç, but of Acalizate Spirits, and tho≈øe of E≈ø≈øential vegitable Sulphurs, he ≈øaith definitively, that their ≈øaline
Acrimony is fat and Sulphuerous, nor ea≈øily or ≈øpeedily reducible into Salt, unle≈øs by a tedious inver≈øion of their whole ≈øub≈øtance; whence I ob≈øerved, that Alcalyes were not to be volatized (duely and truly) but by means of e≈ø≈øential vegetable Oyls or üúçs. Secondly, That being volatized, they retained their Sulphureous fatne≈øs a long time, till by a tedious inver≈øion of the whole ≈øub≈øtance, the Sulphureous nature was turned into a Saline. Thirdly, Yet (even then) tho≈øe ≈øaline Alcalizate ≈øpirits could not give the immortal Liquor, becau≈øe
Meretriciou≈øly addicted to wed any ≈øubject, and by di≈ø≈øolution thereof, to be reduced into a Coagulative volatile Salt, as Helmont expre≈øly teacheth in his Tract. de Feb. as al≈øo in his Tract. de pote≈øt Medicam, his words are the≈øe, If, ≈øaith he, you cannot attain to the Arcanum of our Fire, learn (as a ≈øuccedaneum thereto) to make Alcalyes volatile, and with their Spirits perform your di≈ø≈øolutions; which, although they leave their di≈øsolved Bodies (when dige≈øted in our Stomacks) yet have they by their Di≈ø≈øolution of, and Coagulation upon them, borrowed
≈øo much of their virtue, as by it to be able to overcome most Di≈øea≈øes. And in another place he ≈øaith, If Spirit of Salt of Tartar di≈ø≈øolve Quick-Silver, Silver, ∆≤nicornes Horn, Crabs Eyes, or any other ≈øimple; it will cure (not only all Feavours) but most Di≈øea≈øes indifferently. And without making di≈øtinction; not that I expect the Quick-≈øilver, Silver, &c. ≈øhould pa≈øs with the Spirit into the Veins; but it is ≈øufficient that the Alcalizate Spirit is by means of the≈øe Bodies, reduced into the nature of a Volatile and Coagulable Salt; and in the
Stomack being fir≈øt dige≈øted, (as other Meats are) it it pa≈ø≈øeth into the Me≈øeraicks, being carried thither by the Urine; and in its pa≈ø≈øage re≈øolveth and loo≈øneth whatever ob≈øtructing filth it meets with, by virtue of its Exotick qualities, borrowed in di≈ø≈øolution, from the bodies whereon it was coagulated. And in his Tract. de pote≈øt Med. ≈øpeaking of Alcalyes, I perceived or felt (≈øaith he) that they are utterly void of all ≈øeminal power, or properties, and have only a Saponary, Ab≈øter≈øive, and re≈øolving nature, wherewith they are contented;
except they be made volatile, and then I was ≈øen≈øible that they re-a≈ø≈øumed Bal≈øamick ≈øeminal Vertues, and the radical principles of the≈øe concretes (by who≈øe volatile üúçs they were revived and made volatile.) But adds, I was ≈øen≈øible how ea≈øily the≈øe volatile Alcalyes are tran≈ømuted into new and various forms, ≈øince they unite mo≈øt readily to any Bodyes, and wed therewith: acting according to the native di≈øpo≈øition of the Bodyes, to which they are thus conjunctively a≈ø≈øociated. By the≈øe te≈øtimonyes of this noble and
mo≈øt acute Phylo≈øopher, whom I felt under≈øtandingly, having fir≈øt often read him, and ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øider'd his words, I was wholly confirmed in my opinion concerning Urine, as the only ≈øubject in which this ≈øecret Liquor was to be ≈øought and attained. Which opinion of mine was dayly more and more ≈øtrengthned by ≈øeveral expre≈ø≈øions of his concerning this ≈øubject, one of which I recited before, namely, That Wi≈ødom did (and for ever will) de≈øpi≈øe all ≈øuch who think ≈øcorn to learn by the fire what the contents, nature, and properties of
Urine are, how ≈øordid and contemptible a thing ≈øoever it ≈øeem and appear to be. Therefore in his Tract. concerning the ≈øix dige≈øtions in man, he u≈øeth this expre≈ø≈øion concerning the Salt of Mans Urine, that in the whole ≈øy≈øteme of the Univer≈øe it had not its fellow or peere. Neither Sea nor Fountain Salt, Salt Peter or Gemme; In a word, not any natural Salt what≈øoever, nor yet the Salt of the Urine of Bea≈øts, was comparable to it. The ≈øame he affirms in his Tract de Lith. And in≈øtances in the Urine of a Hor≈øe, which he found far
to fall ≈øhort of the dignity of Mans Urine, not having in it, or by any preparation, yielding that noble Spirit, which in Mans Urine was to be found, which Coagulated Spirit of Urine in an in≈øtant, not into a fixed body, but an Aetherical ≈øubtle, ≈øpiritual Salt, then which nature hath not a more ≈øpiritual penetrative Creature; of the Salt of Urine he before ≈øaid, That he knew not if or no the whole World afforded any thing of a more ≈øubtle nature: comparing which with that Paragraph concerning the Immortal di≈ø≈øolvent in his Tract. de Medicam pote≈øt: he
calls it the highe≈øt and mo≈øt noble of Salts, which hath attained its utmo≈øt pitch in nature of ≈øubtilty and purity, penetrating all things, and is the only agent in the World, which acting upon Bodyes, remains always immutable, and with ea≈øe re≈øolves all things, and brings them into ready obedience, liquefying and (at the ≈øame time) volatizing them, as Snow is melted in warm water. I ob≈øerved, I ≈øay, in the works of this Philo≈øopher, the Liquor Alchahe≈øt, and the Circulated Salt of Paracel≈øus, otherwi≈øe called the greater Circulate,
were Synonimous, and indifferently u≈øed to ≈øignifie this fire of Hell, or immutable di≈ø≈øolvent; and where is it to be found but in that ≈øubject who≈øe Spirit is even ≈øaline, never Acid or Alcalizate? Not without cau≈øe therefore (by way of incouragement) he thus allureth the ≈øtudious ≈øearchers of truth; ≈øeek (my Brethren) and as many of you as are ≈øedulous and diligent ≈øhall find truth ready to meet you with open arms, to embrace you, and crown your ≈øearches with un≈øpeakable joy. Fir≈øt learn to di≈ø≈øolve the Duelech, or Stone of the Bladder
or Reins, or the Gravel of either, in a Gla≈øs with a Tepid Liquor, inoffen≈øive to either Stomack or Bladder, rejoyce, for you are near the great ≈øecret, then learn to di≈ø≈øolve the Ludus, and reduce it into a volatile Salt, &c. Now this Spirit or Liquor which will thus re≈øolve the Duelech, is the ≈øecond, which is drawn from Urine (putrified by long dige≈øtion.) The former Coagulating Spirit (of Aquae Vitae rectified) being ≈øome dayes before taken away by di≈øtillation. From the te≈øtimonyes of this mo≈øt acute and truly adept Philo≈øopher by the fire,
I ≈øet my mind to con≈øider the thing it ≈øelf, and found it a ≈øubject of great wonder. My Experience convinced me, that it was an Anomalous Coagulum, which being it ≈øelf a mo≈øt ≈øubtile Spirit, was yet the Coagulation of other (and none but) Spirits, and tho≈øe only vinous, for although it ≈øeems to Coagulate, it de≈øtroys utterly all acid Spirits, and returns them into Water in≈øipid, or rather the acid Spirit, attempting by its Corro≈øivene≈øs, to de≈øtroy this tender Spirit, which is mo≈øt exqui≈øitely volatile and flying: It the better to defend it ≈øelf,
a≈ø≈øumes the form of a coagulated Body (as Water to with≈øtand the active force of the Cold which would turn it into a Gas, cru≈øts it ≈øelf by its own action, into an Ice) And ≈øo this mo≈øt fugacious penetrative Spirit, plays under the Maske of a far more fixed (yet totally volatile) Body of Salarmoniack, while the Spirit (to avoid who≈øe tyranny it thus di≈øgui≈øed it ≈øelf) is by its own fretting activity totally de≈øtroyed from what it was, and becomes a mere elemental Water: That this Coagulation, and di≈øgui≈øed fixation, with a total ≈øu≈øpen≈øion
of the acute Urinary odour and ta≈øt, i ‚Ä¢ from it ≈øelf, and not the acid Spirit (effectively.) I demon≈øtrate, fir≈øt in that upon any Acidity, fixt or volatile, it will do the ≈øame thing, and become the ≈øame Salt, and ≈øo the acid Calcinate of Vitriol, as well as its acid volatile Spirit will cau≈øe the ≈øame ≈øaline product. But Secondly, were the Urinous Spirit coagulated pa≈ø≈øively, it would be really and actually tran≈ømuted, and become another thing, whereas the ≈øame Urinous Spirit (identically and numerically) is (in this action) but veiled under a
Larva, or masked under the di≈øgui≈øe of a more fixed body (as Water ≈øtill remaining the ≈øame, counterfeits a body of appearing Gla≈øs, being indeed but the ≈øame water identically, in the di≈øgui≈øe of Ice.) And this the affu≈øion of a Lixivium of Salt of Tartar, or any other Alcaly, will ea≈øily di≈øcover, when in the twinkling of an eye, or the ≈øpace of the ≈øame quicke≈øt thought, the ≈øame Spirit of Urine, in the ≈øame pondus & qualities, and with the ≈øame formal properties, will di≈øtill over as before, re-a≈ø≈øuming the ≈øame ≈øubtlety of odour, fieryne≈øs of ta≈øt, being equally Volatile,
coagulating al≈øo Spirit of Wine, ≈øpeedily, powerfully, and ≈øolemnly, as if it had never been coagulated. Whereas the acid Spirit is turned into an in≈øipid Water; having ≈øpent it ≈øelf in vain upon this di≈øgui≈øed Body of Sal Armoniack. And Thirdly, were the coagulation and ≈øemifixation actively from the Corro≈øive Spirit, which is mo≈øt fiery, and in its tumultuous action, cau≈øeth a ≈øen≈øible in≈øufferable heat to the touch, it could not upon a Spirit mo≈øt exqui≈øitely hot and fiery, actually imprint that Lunar Blas, which is apparent in Sal Armoniack:
For it being in nature and quality hot, and materially and really (although hiddenly) containing the mo≈øt fiery Spirit of Urine, of which a drop in an in≈øtant will ve≈øitate the Toung or Lips, as powerfully and ≈øpeedily as the mo≈øt fiery potential cautery; and the Spirit by its mo≈øt acute ≈øharp odour (arguing the mo≈øt exqui≈øite heat of it when rectified) being ≈øo volatile and penetrative, ≈øcarce any ≈øtopple can keep it confin'd to the Ve≈ø≈øel which contains it; and ≈øo piercingly acute, that no humane, or other Animals Organs of ≈ømelling can long
endure its odour, without a threatned Syncope, if not an Apoplexie for the time doth yet ≈øo powerfully operate by a Lunar Blas, that if Sal Armoniack be put in an Urinal, or other thick Gla≈øs, and water poured on it, ≈øtraightway it cau≈øeth ≈øuch an extremity of Cold, as will actually freeze Water on the out≈øide of the Urinal, yea although
antimony , or üúç, or ‚òø, be ≈øublimed with it, which are of a hot fiery Nature; And this Lunar Blas is in≈øperable from it as long as it appears in the form of a more fixed Body of Salt, where ob≈øerve by the by, that
Cold is a real po≈øitive Ens or Being, and not a bare privation of heat, as the Schools mo≈øt coldly teach. (It is I ≈øay) a Being which in the twinkling of an eye, can by the irradiating Blas of moi≈øtned Sal Armoniack be ≈øent through the impervious ≈øides of a ≈øtrong Gla≈øs, ≈øo as in an in≈øtant to produce Cold in its glaciating extream, which was not ≈øo the moment before. Therefore Secondly, this cannot be an impre≈ø≈øion ≈øtampt upon the mo≈øt fiery Corro≈øive; but is done by the activity of the Urinous Spirit upon it ≈øelf, which it is ≈øo ≈øollicited too by
the excitation of the Corro≈øive Spirit, as Water actually cru≈øt it ≈øelf with Ice, by the Irritation of extream Cold, which otherwi≈øe threatens ruine to its pre≈øent form of Exi≈øtence. And Thirdly, By a peculiar priviledge the Creaator hath given this Spirit, the mo≈øt Cold Lunar Blas, marries it ≈øelf to this (naturally hot in quality) ≈øubject, which it influentially imprints on what≈øoever it toucheth; ≈øo ≈øoon as moi≈øture (over which the cold Moon by its Light is pre≈øident) is poured on its Body; that the Atomes of Water and Salt do embrace
each other. Fourthly, no marvell, ≈øince the Lunar influence (having dominion over moi≈øture) is the main in≈øtrument of reducing things to their fir≈øt matter (as is evident in Inke, Broth, Jellies, Fle≈øh, or Fi≈øh, once throughly Frozen) that the acid Corro≈øive Spirits, (which acting their fury upon Bodies, are variou≈øly coagulated into fixt coagulated Salts, of times very Corro≈øive) are in this action, by a retrograde reduction, brought into mere in≈øipid Elemental Water: For let the Corro≈øive Spirit be of what kind ≈øoever, Acetous, Vitriolate,
Nitrous of Salt Gemme, Sea Salt, or any other acidity, the product of Sal Armoniack is ≈øtill the ≈øame, as al≈øo the Lunar Blas inhering in it, if not appearing with the ≈øame countenance at fir≈øt coagulation, yet by ≈øublimation of the coagulated Salt, the identity is ≈øoon perceptible; and the ≈øame reduction of the Corro≈øive Spirit to in≈øipid Water, is as well the end of one acidity as another; By which the action of the Spirit upon it ≈øelf, (not ≈øuffering a pa≈ø≈øive coagulation from the acid Corro≈øive) is beyond di≈øpute, and out of que≈øtion.

So then this is the original and production of Sal Armoniack the mo≈øt ≈øubtle acute penetrative Urinous Spirit, meeting with an acid Corro≈øive; this ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ eks (by a furious a≈ø≈øault, to de≈øtroy that; which to prevent, the Urinous Spirit, counterfeits a Body by a ≈øpontaneus Coagulation, which (as more permanent) it oppo≈øeth to the fury of the Corro≈øive ≈øpiritual Acidity. Into this Body the Lunar Blas concenteates, and joins it ≈øelf, dwelling in it invi≈øibly, yet acting vi≈øibly.

The acid Spirit, fretting it ≈øelf in vain upon this wonderful body, receiving a determination from its Cold Lunar Blas, ends in the total extinction of its ≈øaline ≈øeminal virtue, and that which in other actings, receives from various bodies, various coagulations, into divers forms of Salts fixed from this counterfeit body (guarded by a Lunar Blas (or influence) receives its final de≈øtruction, and b ‚Ä¢ comes in≈øipid) Elemental water; thus that the Spirit through itr own activity is exantlated (by a fru≈øtaneous acting on this larvated body) is from
it ≈øelf; But that the end of this fury, and excande≈øcence, ≈øhould be the total extinction of its ≈øaline life, or being, is wholly to be attributed to the Lunar Blas, which is intimately and in≈øeparately wedded to the form of Sal Armoniack; who≈øe coagulation into that di≈øgui≈øe of a body, is by its own action, on it ≈øelf, according to an unerring in≈øtinct by which the wi≈øe Creator hath injoyn'd it to act.

This I have de≈øcribed the more at large, that the ≈øtudious might lay this true relation of this anomalous Generation, as a ≈øure foundation to
work upon in the mo≈øt ≈øeeret di≈øcovery of what only a true mental man will intellectually apprehend, and intuitively behold, with the clear ≈øight of the Soul or mind. For as there is a Sal Armoniack Vulgar, which ≈øcarce any Fool but knows; ≈øo is there al≈øo a Sal Armoniack of Philo≈øophers, which only true elect Sons of Learning know: In the circulation of which, is the perfection of the hope of all true adept Brothers of Art, ≈øo far as concerns this ≈øire of Hell, which is Fire and yet Water, Water, and yet no Water, Air, and yet
conden≈øible, not Corro≈øive, yet the mo≈øt ≈øharp and perpetual Corro≈øive: A choice Medicine, clean≈øing and purifying Nature, yet the de≈øtroyer and conquerour of Bodies. But vinous Spirits are actually and actively coagulated by Spirit of Urine, and it ≈øelf is actually con-coagulated with them, of which coagulation Helmont gives not an unlike Elogium, to that of the Immortal Liquor it ≈øelf; namely, That it is not made by a bare a≈ø≈øociation of parts, but a marrying of each to other in the bond of indi≈ø≈øolveable unity, a production
of a new Ens, which is a neutral, mo≈øt ≈øubtle, ≈øpiritual body, di≈øtinct from either parent. Here is a ≈øpiritual body ari≈øing from two, yet without any diver≈øity of ferment, for a vinous Spirit is intimate, and centrally one with the Spirit of Mans Urine, by virtue and efficacy of which, it coagulates Spirit of Wine, and is coagulated it ≈øelf, which cannot happen to any Urinous Spirit, unle≈øs by the influential power of a vinous; which is the only coagulable object (primarily) of Spirit of Urine. With which, if it meet with any other volatile
Spirit, e≈ø≈øentially united, it coagulates it ≈øelf therewith, ≈øo the Oils of Spices, and odoriferous Vegetables, being fir≈øt intimately a≈ø≈øociated to a Urinous Spirit, are with it coagulated together into one ≈øpiritual body by rectifi'd Spirit of Urine; and truly, upon ≈øerious con≈øideration, the univer≈øallity of the nature and energy of Urine in its Spirit, cannot ≈øufficiently be admir'd. For (mediately at the lea≈øt) there is nothing in the whole univer≈øe (except the central heart of ‚òø, and one thing which alone is its compere, the one de≈øtroying it, the other
untoucht by its activity) which is not either by it tran≈ømuted into its own nature, or el≈øe ab≈øolutely de≈øtroy'd, and reduced into clear and elemental water.

For demon≈øtrating this, it will not be ami≈øs to take an exact ≈øurvey, at lea≈øt briefly of all ≈øublimary Concrete Bodyes. In the Mineral Kingdom, the central heart of ‚òø, (as was above≈øaid) excepted, all Sulphurs, mettaline and mineral, yea even of ‚òâ, ‚òΩ, and ‚òø them≈øelves, are by reiterate cohobations, turned into ≈øaline Liquors, or Spirits, and they at la≈øt return to in≈øipid
elemental Water; ≈øo all Stones not calcinable by this ≈øire of Hell, are made into Salts, which by oft circulating or cohobating with this Liquor, are volatiz'd, and by addition return a ‚Ä¢ la≈øt into Water. All calcinable ≈øtones and ≈øhells, yield an Alcaly, which being by e≈ø≈øential Oyls volatized, unite with rectifi'd Spirit of Wine, and are concoagulated by an Urinous Spirit; which ≈øubtle Coagulum, being by a convenient acidity made into a more abiding bodily Salt, and ≈øublimed, whatever will not formally abide therewith, is ≈øeparated
≈øtraightway in form of an Heterogeneous Liquor, and by an ea≈øie art is robb'd of its ≈øeminal Cra≈øis, and returns to in≈øipid water. All Animals, their Fle≈øh, Bloud, and Bones, be≈øides a Mercurial Liquor (which is ≈øoon turn'd to elementary water) give a fat Sulphur, and an urinary Salt, if not by immediate di≈øtillation, yet by a previous maceration by ferment and putrifaction. The Caput Mort becomes by the cohobation of our Circulated Salt, a mere Salt, and at la≈øt becomes Water, as all Earths, Stones, or the like, the Urinary Salts
being purified by rectification, and ≈øemifixed into a more permanent body by proper Acidities, become a Sal Armoniack; which in ≈øublimation (lo≈øing its Heterogeneityes) ari≈øes univocally the ≈øame with other of the ≈øame kind. The fat by di≈øtillation is volatized, and by an Alcaly becomes ≈øu≈øceptible of union with Spirit of Wine, and con≈øequently of con-coagulation by an Urinous Spirit, and by acidityes proper is made a Sal Armoniack.

The Urine of all Creatures giving a Spirit, is by an acidity made a tractable body
of Salt, and by ≈øubliming with other Sal Armoniack; what is not made one identically therewith, is ≈øeparated as Heterogeneus, and by an ea≈øie art totally de≈øtroyed. All horns and hoofs, either immediately, or being before buried, yield an Oyle, and an Urinous Salt; and may be handled, as I ≈øaid before, in the like ca≈øe, of the ≈øame products of Fle≈øh, Bloud, and Bones. All Trees by burning, give a fixt Alcalid Mercurial Liquor, a volatile Sulphur, and a volatile Salt in the ≈øoot, which is plainly and truly Urinous; ≈øome Spices, Flowers,
Seeds, Barks and Roots of Trees, give an E≈ø≈øential Oyle, others expre≈øt Oyle: at lea≈øt, all expre≈øt Oyles by reiterate di≈øtillations, being rectifi'd and cohobated with Alcalyes, become capable of union with Spirit of Wine, and con≈øequently of coagulation by, and ≈øubjugation too, Urinous Spirits; which with whatever will not hold coagulation and ≈øublimation, is ≈øeparated as Heterogeneall, and ea≈øily reducible to in≈øipid Water. The de≈øtruction of all acid Spirits (by urinous) I taught before. In a word, whatever in the World is (be≈øide
the cential Nut of
arsenic ) is either fixt or volatile, the fixt, either ≈øaline or not, what is not ≈øaline, by art is made ≈øo, and both (by art and pains) become volatile; and being volatized, are ≈øoon reduced to Elemental Water, robb'd of all ≈øeminal virtue; fixt Alcalyes are volatized, marryed with vinous Spirits; and coagulable (together with them) by means of Urinous: Oyles become Salts Volatile, and ≈øo commi≈øcible with Spirits of Wine, and ≈øo tran≈ømutable by Urinous: Vinous Spirits are mo≈øt univer≈øal, all Herbs, Roots, Barks, Fruits,
Honey, Suggar, Leaves, Grain≈øeeds, Flowers, &c. yielding (by fermentation) a true vinous Spirit, which (by reiterate rectifications) loo≈øing the qualities of the (media vita) of its concrete, is not di≈øcernable from others, and is (pari jure) coagulable in Spirit of Urine, (exqui≈øitely deflegmed) which being then reduced to a more fixt Sal Armoniack, if not by it ≈øelf, yet by ≈øubliming (together) with that which is the product of humane Urine, becomes one (homogeneally) with it, and whatever (with it) abides the te≈øt of ≈øublimation, in that
more fixed bodily form, is ever after univocally, homogeneally, and identically the ≈øame, hath the ≈øame Lunar Blas, and being reviv'd with an (Alcaly, or otherwi≈øe) gives the ≈øame coagulating Spirit, which will coagulate Spirit of Wine. Behold here the admirable nature of the Spirit of Mans Urine, how it plays its part among all other Concretes, Spirits, Acetous, Oleagenous, Vinous, Alcalizate, and Urinous; As Aarons Rod did with the Rods of Pharaohs Inchanters, it devoured them all, either a≈ø≈øimulating them to it ≈øelf in
matter and form, or de≈øtroying and reducing them (at la≈øt) to mere in≈øipid Elemental Water. Here you have a body at la≈øt of an admirable product (not Vulgar but Philo≈øophical Sal Armoniack) concerning which, I have very much yet to write, howbeit, my writings will be more knotty then Apollo's Oracles, till you learn to di≈øtingui≈øh between Sal Armoniack Vulgar and Philo≈øophical.

div.head: The unheard of Heteroclyte Doctrin of Sal Armoniack, both ∆≤ulgar and Philo≈øophical.
div.p:
IN my Pyrotechny A≈ø≈øerted and Illu≈øtrated, which contains the Second and Third part, accounting my vindication of Helmont, and Explication of Nature for the fir≈øt part, being originally in Latine wrote together,
and making with my other Writings but one Volume, I writing of the Immortal Liquor, or Fire, did paraphra≈øtically interpret that place of Helmont. Ars indagando ≈øollicita e≈øt Corpori, quod tantae puritatis Symphonia colluderet nobi≈øcum, ut a corrumpente nequirent di≈ø≈øipaeri, ac tandem ≈øtupefacta e≈øt Religio, reperta latice, &c. To which place, I ≈øhall remit the Reader, for what is there ≈øpoken too, not intending here a repetition, but a further illu≈øtration of things more briefly or ob≈øcurely di≈øcour≈øed of there. I ob≈øerved it to be a Body,
which Art was ≈øo inqui≈øitively ≈øollicitous to find, but ≈øuch a one, as might play with us or make us ≈øport (colluderet) by its harmony of ≈øo great purity, as not to be capable of di≈ø≈øipation, by means of any corruptive agent or in≈øtrument; ≈øuch play or ≈øport is more plea≈øant to a true Arti≈øt, then the Lords of the Phili≈øtins could have expected from Samp≈øon, yet this pulls down, and de≈øtroys as he did, (not Hou≈øes) but the mo≈øt ≈øolid compact bodies; and Champion like maintains its ground, although very few Gallants and Ladies have that happyne≈øs
to ≈øee the prizes plaid by this Anomalous Combatant. This body I there forbore to di≈øcover, except my≈øtically and parabolically; but here I ≈øhall plainly enough, to a Son of Art, di≈øcover the ≈øame, It is as I ≈øaid, a Body of a Spiritual inde≈øtructible Salt, in plain terms, it is the Salt of Humane Urine, or Sal Armoniack, not Vulgar (the product of Urine, Soot, and Sea-Salt) but Philo≈øophical, to which the Vulgar is related, as ‚òø Vulgar, is to the ‚òø of the Philo≈øophers. The que≈øtion now will be how this Sal Armoniack Philo≈øophical
is made, which I think I have ≈øufficiently declared to a Son of Art; but I ≈øhall be a little more plainer and candid in my di≈øcovery, That mo≈øt acute ≈øubtile penetrative Spirit of Mans Urine, by the help of another medium, not of a diver≈øe ferment from it ≈øelf, but centrally one I ≈øay with it, mu≈øt be united to an Acidum, not Corro≈øive, ≈øed naturae ≈øuae grati≈ø≈øimum. This Acidum mu≈øt be equally volatile with the Salt of Urine, before it can be Married or United intimately with it. Then by often Circulations it attains that height of purity to be entituled
Ens ≈øalium, ≈øummum ≈øalium & falici≈ø≈øimum. After all this, I mu≈øt conclude with that ≈øaying of the mo≈øt excellent Helmont in another ca≈øe, Chap. de Feb. ≈øpeaking there concerning the Aurum Horizontale, Tamet≈øi paucis ab≈øolvi ≈øecretum quod medicum nobilitat i≈øtudque para≈ø≈øe pro primo vice ingentis operis e≈øt pendetque directio a manu ejus qui dator e≈øt omnium donorum bonorum. So I may well ≈øay in this, although I have di≈øcover'd the matter more plainly then any other, yet when attained, the way of working with it, is not ea≈øie, but depends from
his teaching who is the giver of every perfect gift; to who≈øe Tutoridge I leave the hone≈øt inquirer and ≈øearcher after Truth.

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: PAge 4. r. in the Microco≈øme, p. 9. r. Sulphureous, idem p. 10. p. 17. for Urine r: Wine, idem for Aetherical r. Aetherial, p. 19. for even r. sver, p. 20. for the r. he, p. 32. for ≈øaeks r. ≈øeeks, p. 39. for ≈øublimary r. ≈øublunary, p. 43. for Alcalid r. Alcaly.
